repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Republic of - Transparency and
            Governance Repeat Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Transparency and
            Governance Repeat Project for Congo, Republic of were as
            follows: outcomes were unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            political and governance risks need to be carefully
            mitigated in project design to ensure financial
            sustainability. Among the political risks to be factored in
            is that the Bank itself will be hesitant to apply remedies
            in case the client fails on its financial commitment to
            preserve client relationship. A governance project should,
            whenever possible, contribute to the international agenda on
            aid effectiveness, including the commitment by development
            partners to use country systems. A PIU needs to be endowed
            by the government with both operational capacity and the
            authority on beneficiary agencies to ensure adequate
            internalization of the project inputs. For that purpose,
            active support from political authorities is indispensable.
            Their piloting of the project should ensure the alignment of
            the project with the political agenda, alert the Bank and
            the PIU of any policy shifts, and impose interagency
            coordination across public entities benefitting from the
            project. Some of the decisions which were needed for the
            project to remain meaningful and be successful belong
            exclusively to the political leadership. The project could
            not perform as expected for want of sufficient leadership on
            the part of the authorities. Project coordination is a
            full-time responsibility from which the project coordinator
            and the PIU should not have been taken out.

repnme.cdata!:
Congo - Second Phase of the Transparency
            and Governance Capacity Building Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Second
            Phase of the Transparency and Governance Capacity Building
            Project for Congo is to strengthen the capacity of targeted
            public sector ministries, agencies and accountability
            structures for improved management of human and financial
            resources. There are three components to the project. The
            first component is increased capacity of targeted ministries
            to manage financial and human resources. The objective of
            this component is to provide support to further increase
            transparency and accountability in financial operations
            through technical assistance, provision of equipment and
            training in budget and human resources management, and
            procurement. It also includes technical support to extend
            the rapid results approach in selected ministries. The
            second component is strengthened capacity to ensure public
            sector accountability and transparency. The objective of
            this component is to support the Independent Governance
            Observatory, the Governmental Anti-Corruption Commission,
            the Economic and Financial Commission of Parliament, the
            Supreme Audit Institution, the State General Inspectorate,
            Media and selected Non-Government Organizations (NGOs) by
            providing technical assistance and training to enhance their
            capacity to monitor governance and anti corruption measures.
            The third component is monitoring and evaluation system. The
            objective of this component is to ensure the effective
            management and coordination of project implementation.

Congo - Second Phase of the Transparency and
